awd_titl_txt: Madison Moduli Weekend - A Conference on Moduli Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
'Madison Moduli Weekend' is a conference on moduli spaces to be held in Madison, Wisconsin between the 27th and 29th of March, 2020. Moduli spaces are of great significance in algebraic geometry and number theory, and a great number of perspectives have developed in order to study them. This conference aims to bring together a diverse group of mathematicians, ranging from early career graduate students to experts in this field, to discuss the big questions and techniques surrounding the study of moduli spaces. The conference will consist of five plenary lectures as well as multiple short talks by early career mathematicians. More details can be found at the conference website: https://sites.google.com/wisc.edu/madisonmoduliweekend/home.

Moduli spaces parametrize families of objects of interest, up to a notion of isomorphism. Their study has motivated the development of many areas in arithmetic and algebraic geometry, in addition to having a significant impact on them. These include, but are not limited to the study of modular curves, Shimura varieties, Hurwitz spaces and the theory of stacks. The goal of this conference is to talk about both the arithmetic and the geometry of moduli spaces. The plenary speakers of this conference study moduli spaces in various contexts, including rational points, vector bundles, the theory of stacks, Brauer groups, K-theory and Hodge theory. Four of the five plenary talks will be preceded by preparatory talks aimed at graduate students and early postdoctoral researchers. The conference is aimed at an audience of mathematicians with a broad interest in algebraic geometry and number theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The main outcome of the grant was the Madison Moduli Weekend, a conference held (virtualy) in September 2020.  Approximately 140 participants, mostly graduate students, attended the workshop.  The conference included 12 research lectures and two sessions of "lightning talks" where early-career participants could present their work.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT:  The workshop lectures introduced graduate students to a wide range of topics around moduli, ranging from arithmetic geometry (Zureick-Brown) to the interface between algebraic geometry and topology (Antieau.)  

BROADER IMPACT:  We believe that the conference served as a community-building experience for early-career mathematicians in this part of algebraic geometry, which was especially important during the early months of the pandemic.  

The Jan-Dec 2021 time period represents a no-cost extension for the original proposal for the Madison Moduli Weekend. The conference, originally planned as an in-person event, was held virtually in September 2020.  Since the conference was virtual, we had essentially no expenses; our plan was to use the allotted funds to hold a follow-up in-person conference in 2021.  However, pandemic conditions prevented us following through on that plan.  Since my co-organizer on this project (Soumya Sankar) has moved on from Madison, I have not filed another no-cost extension, the original purpose of the grant having been fulfilled by the 2020 conference.


Last Modified: 05/11/2022
Modified by: Jordan S Ellenberg
